Claremont School District Fall 2020 Opening Update

The survey ended last night at 8:00PM. Today, staff spent time calling families that did not respond. They will be reaching out to more families on Tuesday. We have a meeting on Wednesday to go over the information from the survey, which includes families' choices on the education of their children this fall. We are putting together students living in the same household into cohorts (prek-12). Then, we need to look at transportation. Once we have this completed, we will reach out to families. We are very pleased to say that we have 1,031 students accounted for on our survey. The first day of school has changed from August 31 to September 3 to assist us in preparing our buildings and staff. I hope this helps. If you are not receiving emails or phone calls from the school, please call your child's school to make sure we have the correct information.

Good afternoon, this is Michael Tempesta, Superintendent of Schools for SAU 6 in Claremont and Unity New Hampshire.

I am contacting you to follow-up on the Governor Sununu’s 1 pm press conference earlier today in which he directed all schools to immediately transition to remote learning. Students will not be reporting to school beginning tomorrow and continuing for the next few weeks until April 3, 2020, when the situation regarding the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) pandemic will be re-assessed and new guidance will be given.

To be clear, no students will be reporting to school in Unity and Claremont, NH, beginning tomorrow. All faculty and staff will be reporting to their schools to begin planning remote learning for our students. We will be communicating our remote learning expectations, procedures and logistics to students and families throughout the week.

I want to thank everyone for their patience and support throughout this very challenging COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic.

We are fortunate to have a very close-knit, caring school community and we will all get through this together.

post_text: 2Y became germ busting experts. We used germ simulating lotion to “dirty up” our hands. We looked at our germy hands under a black light and talked about the best way to remove those “germs” from our hands, washing for 20 to 30 seconds with warm soapy water. We then looked under the black light again to see if we missed any areas and where we could wash more next time. Common culprits were fingernails, in between our fingers and our wrists. 2Y LOVED this germ busting job!

post_text:
In Mr. Bilodeau's Project Based Learning (PBL), students worked on "Survive the New Hampshire Wilderness".

A group of sixteen 6th grade students looked at the basic needs for survival. They learned how to meet those needs with limited resources and tools. They also learned about the basics of, and science of, heat loss. Students applied that knowledge to create debris huts that could be used in survival situations. They also discovered about water purification and the science behind it. Although they did not create fire, students learned some of the science of fire. They looked at what fire needs in addition to the chemical reaction that occurs for combustion. Mr. Bilodeau demonstrated the use of a bow drill to create a fire from friction.
